abstract.p: Diana L Smith letter on Susan Allen Toth's August 27 travel article on Channel Islands recalls garden tour that included Guernsey and Sark (S)

To the Editor: Susan Allen Toth's article ''A Foot in Two Countries,'' (Aug. 27), about the Channel Islands, was much needed for American travelers but missed some attractive and important sites. A few years ago I took a garden tour that included Guernsey and Sark.

On Guernsey, Ms. Toth glosses over Victor Hugo's home in exile, Hauteville House, with its extraordinary yet sumptuous decor. Many furnishings were the spoils of privateering: sections of woodwork and paneling; cabinets, sideboards and seats; tapestries, china, bric-a-brac..

Our tour group enjoyed a nature walk along the cliffs in Forest Parish with a naturalist guide, and the wildflowers were unforgettable. We also visited huge greenhouses of roses and carnations. Ms. Toth mentions Sausmarez woodland garden. But more interesting is a guided tour of the manor itself, where one sees, among other things, King James II's wedding attire and the original log of a rich treasure-collection voyage.
Guernsey's capital of St. Peter was covered but it is also a huge yacht and marine center, reminiscent of Newport, R.I. -- with a historic fort overlooking it.
